(podpis inwestora) m Pouczenie: Stoonnie do an. 54 — Ustmy Prawo budowane zmiadonienie dokonuje się o najnniej 21 dni przed zamierzonym terninem przystąpienia do użykowani Stosownie do art, 57 ust. 1 3— Prawa budowlanego dołączam: 4." orygliał dziewka budowy, 3. adsiadzena kierownika bidony: +" zgode wykonania obikn budowanego zprojekem budowłarym I warka pozwolenia na budowę ocz przepi, 1 o doprowadzenia do natztegostam i porządku teremt budowy, a także = w razie korzytania z ulicy, sqiediej ierchomości, budynku lub lokalu, 3. ośwładczenie o włatehiym zagospodarowaniu terenów przyległych, jeżeli eksploatacja wybudowanego obiektu jest uzależnłona od leh odpowiedniego zegospodaroneiia +... imtetayzeję geodezyjna porałowniczj, 5. proroofę bai sprawdze +" mra wodno-kanalccyjnej, elekycznej gzowej l przewod komin, 6. potwiedzede, zgodności z odrębnymi przepiiam,odbioni wykonanych przyłącz 5... pozwolenie badowę wraz: dokmientacją techniczny obiku (załączyć b wgląd, 5." owiadzenieo braku sozechwu PIS, PIR, PSP, 3... kopię władca chaakiersyk ouergerczej buku. UWAGA: Do składania wniosków o wydanie pozwolenia na użytkowanie abiektu (budynków) jak i odbioru decyzji o pozwoleniu na użytkowanie, nprawnieni są właściciele lub_osoby_ posiadające upoważnienia. pisemne od_ wiaśieiela z potwierdzoną przez organ gdinisracji własnorecznościę pods właelelia

Z dnia ZSZ, NdZIE|OKEBO pRZEZCADYPSO SHATBE eee W związku z powyższym wnoszę o udzielenie pozwolenia na użyikowanie w/w. obiektu budowlanego. * - Należy zakreślić kółkiem odpowiedni symbol: Oświadczam, że budynek jest wyposażony zgodnie z projektem, w następujące instalacje i urządzenia: 1. wodociąg (ujęcie własne) / wodociąg ż sieci, 2. ustęp spłukiwany / ustęp spłukiwany z odprowadzeniem do sieci, 3... lazienka, 4. - centralne ogrzewanie, 5... instalacja cieplej wody dostarczanej centralnie, 6. gaz sieciowy. (podpis imwestorn) Pouczenie: + Stosownie do ar. 54 — Ustawy Prawo budowlane zawładomienie dokonuje sę, co najmniej 27 dm przed zawierzonym tekmiiem przystąpienia do teytkowania, Stotownie dogr. 57 ut. 13 - Prawa budowanego dołącza: . 1; oryginał dziemutka budowy, 2... oświadczenie kierownika budowy: +. ozgodności wykonania obiektu budowlanego z projektem budowlanym i warunkami pozwolenia na budowę oraz przepisanii, + o dzprowadzenia do nalżstego sam I porządku term budowy, a także — w razie korzystania niy, sąsiedniej nłeruchomości bucha Lib tokalu, : 3, oświadczenie o właściwym zagospodarowaniu terenów przyległych, jeżeli eksploatacja wybudowanego obiektu jest uzałeżniona od ich odpowiedniego zagospodarowania 4, imientaryzacjęgeodezyjną powykonawczą, 3. protokoły badań i sprawdzeń: _" ustalacji: wodho-kanelzacyjnej, ełekoyeznej gazowej I przewodoń kominowe, 46." polerdzent, zgodności z odrębnymi przepkani, odblori wykonany przyłączy 7. powolnie na budowę wraz z dołamemacj techniczną obiek (załączyć do wgląd, 3, otwiadezenie o braku sprzechwu IS, PIP, FSP, 9, kopię śwladećnwa charakierywyki energetycznej budynku. UWAG: Do składania wniosków o wydanie pozwołenia na użytkowanie obiekui (budynków) jak 1 odbioru decyzji o pozwofeniu na użytkowanie, uprawnieni sq właściciele lub osoby posiadające upoważnienia pisenmie_od właściciela z potwierdzomą, przez organ administracji własnoręcznością podpisu właściciela.

Text Adam: TOBACCO INSTITUTE SPOKESMEN AVAILABLE TO PAN sa The Tobacco Institute bas gained national attention by providing industry spokesmen for speaking engagements across the country. Any TAN member who belongs to a civie elub, such as kotary or Kiwanis, can book one of the TI spokesmen to appear at a local club meeting. The spokesmen have travelled nearly one million miles and appeared before thousands of groups. Their message is "Freedom of Choice" and "Less Government Interven- tion" for smokers and nonsmokers. They don't sell cigarettes. They don't try to make smokers out of non- śmokers or try to discourage someone who wants to quit. What they will do is meke an articulate and persuasive argument in favor of fewer controls on our private lives. Arranging for a TI spokesman to appear in your community is as easy as pickinę up the phone. Call your State Director or call Jada Smith on our toll-free WATS number, 800/424-9876. You may also send in the coupon which appears in the ad below. This is a reprint of our ad > which appeared in the Wall Street Journal earlier this year. We'11 do our best tó have someone speak to your elub or organization in the near future. Text ING: Lizclaiborne_ See Where It Takes You 8 1 Curo iot Woman Curo or on @uine

fAlJ TL Susxe Smoking inpublic: Lets separatefact from friction There has always been some friction between smokers and non-smokers But lately this frictionhas grown more heated. The controversy has been fueled by questionable reports which claim that 'second-hand smoke" is a cause ofserious diseasesamongnon-smokers_ But; in fact; there is little evidence and certainly nothing Which prowes scientifically-that cigarette smoke causes disease innon-Smokers: Skeptics might = this the wishful thinkingofatobacco company But consider the scientific judgment of some of the leading authorities in the field_including outspoken critics ofsmoking: For example, in 1983 the organizer of an international conference on environ- mental tobacco smoke (ETS) summarized the evidenceon lung canceras follows: "Anoverall evaluation based upon available scientific data leads to the conclusion that increased risk for non-smokers from ETS exposure has not been established"" Even the chief statistician of the  American Cancer Society Lawrence Garfinkel; has gone on record as saying;  "passive smoking may be a political matter; but it is nota main issue in terms ofhealth policy" Which brings US back to our original point: cigarette smoke can be annoying to non-smokers Buthow shall weasa society deal with this problem? Confrontation? Segregation? Legislation? No. We think annoyance is neither a governmental problem nor a medical problem: Itsa people problem Smokers and non-smokers have to talk to one aother: Not yell, preach threaten, badger or bully Talk Smokers can help by being more considerate and responsible Non-smokers can help by being more tolerant; And both groups can help by showing more respect for each othersrights and feelings: But eliminating rumor and rhetoric will help most ofall Because when you stick to the facts,itsa lot easier to deal with the friction: 8 RJReynolds_Tbacco Company RETROLD TOLAccO call very
Text Adam: , 2 + WECETORZE " . . | . Smoking in public: ng In DUDLIC: Let. te fact f Ę | | rom IricUon. There has always been some friction between smokers and non-smokers. But lately this friction has grown more heated. "The controversy has been fueled by questionable reports which claim that "second-hand smoke” isa cause ofserious diseases among non-smokers. But, in faci, there is little evidence—and certainly nothing which broves scientifcaliymthat cigarelie stoke causes diszase in non-smokers. Skeptics might call this the wishful thinkingofatobacco company. But consider the scientific judgment of some of the leading authorities in the field—including outspoken critics of smoking, For example, in 1983 the organizer of an international conference on environ- mental tobacco smoke (ETS) sumnmaarized the evidence onlung cancer as follows: "An overall evaluation based upon available scientific data leads to the conelusion that an increased risk for non-smokers from ETS exposure has not been established" WS 7 8 Bven the chief statistician of the American Cancer Society, Lawrence Ze Garfinkel, has gone on record as saying, "passive smoking may be a political | "Be matter, but it is not a niain issue in terms of health policy” Which brings us back to our original point: cigarette smoke can be very I annoying to non-smokers. H But how shall we asa society deal with this problem? SK Confrontation? Segrepation? Legislation? > No. We think annoyance is neither a governmental problem nor a medical 7 problem. Itsa people problem. Ń ! Smokers and non-smokers have to talk to one another. Not yell, preach, threaten, badger or bully. Talk. Smokers can help by being more considerate and responsible. Non-smokers can help by being more tolerant. And both groups can help by showing more respect for each other$ rights and feelings. u Buteliminating rumor and rhetoric will help most ofall. E Because when youstick to the facts, itsa łot easier to deal with the friction. w a EJ s NEA R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company *

Text Adam: p VICE PRESIDENT FEDERAL RELATIONS A major trade association located in downtown Washington seeks an exparienced professional to direct its Federal Relatians Division. The successful candidate will be responsible for coordinating federal legislative and regulatory aciivities of the association, its member companies, and coalition groups. Text ING: Field Sales Responsibilities WNSTON Disclosure Agreement  Ensure all WINSTON PDI at retail has disclosure label in monthly and quarterly calls by 7/15/99. Ensure all WINSTON POS is changed to POS including the disclosure label beginning 1999 and completed no later than July 15, 1999 in all monthly and quarterly calls Ensure all temporary displays and promotional sleeves without disclosure statement are removed from wholesale and relail calls no later than 15, 1999 This would include any displays or promotions produced prior to May 1, 1999. Refer to FSC-31-99 for specific details_ 8 8 May - July

It was the first increase in cigarette prices since April 1996. Philip Morris VSA, the biggest U.5. kobacco maker with brands Like Marlboro and Virginia Sline, and othr tobacco companies made no inmediate move to match the price hike. But analysts said they expected the industry would do so within days. Zaamvel Goldnan, who follows the industry fox Paineebber, said the announced increase came abont a nonth earlier than expected, and he said Reynolds probably moved to head off hoaxding by whoiesalere in anticipation Of a price hike. Text ING: NCV-18-1990 10:25 FROM SMOKEFREE EDUCATIONAL SVC 4656525 P.02/07 Smokefree Educational Services PRESS RELEASE Incorported Contact: Joe Cherner 375 South End Avcnuc, Suite 32P Phone: 839338968 Ncv York NY 10280 Fax:; 488-8911  WOMEN DOCTORS MARK GREAT AMERICAN SMOKEOUT BY PICKETING VIRGINIA SLIMS TENNIS The Women's Medical Association of New York City paid = house call to Madison Garden on November lAth 430-S.30pm,_and November lSth5.30-6.0pm2 to protest Virginia Slims sponsorship of women'$ tennis: Women doctors wearing lab coats and stethoscopes joined health advocates dressed in tennis attire to carry placards and distribute informative flyers to tournament goers and passers-by. The theme for the event: YOUVE COUCHED UP ENOUGH PHLEGM BABY Other placard slogans included, Yes Virginia, there is lung cancer;" Tennis is sport; its smoking that'$ the racket;' and "Billy Jean Billy Jean receives money from Philip Morris t0 promote Virginia Slims tennis  Keeping in that vain, another placard had dollar signs around the border and read; "Why are these women pushing cigarettes?" Due in large part to Virginia Slims cigarettes, lung cancer has overtaken breast cancer as the leading cancer killer of American women   Women's Medical Association President Dr: Barbara Bartlik says, "New York Citys women physicians find it unconscionable for a cigarette company to sponsor & sporting event  Philip Morris, manufacturer of Virginia Slims, sponsors women $ tennis to deccive young girls about the 1 unhealthy consequences of smoking;' Joe Cherner; President of Smokefree Educational Services, notes; "Philip Morris cannot get professional women tennis players to endorse cigarettes; because professional 1 women tennis players don't smoke   Therefore, Virginia Slims sponsors the entire 1 05 tournament t0 link its unhealthy product with healthy activity:' (~more-) WARNING: Secondhand smoko causes dlsease_ Includlng lung cancer: Square King - Drug King:

Text ING: GA CDC-Smoking-Teens, 740 Smoking Teens Respond to Cigarette Advertising ATLANTA (AP) The three most heavily advertised cigarette brands depicted by Joe CameL the Marlboro Man and the couples of Newport captured 86 percent of the teen-age market accounting for only 35 percent of overall sales, according t0 new study released Thursday The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that based on the data showing that advertising influences brand preference among teens, legislation may be needed t0 restrict cigarette advertising_ The results are pretty striking; We were shocked by the magnitude in the difference said Michael Eriksen director of the CDCs Oflice on Smoking and Health. It shows thar advertising not only wOrkS_ but works better for teens than adults_ Is it true? Absolutely said Jonn P. Pierce_ head of the Cancer Prevention and Control Program at the University of California_ San Cancer Center in La Jolla What We re seeing here iS_ the kids are smoking only the brands with huge advertising campaigns not the generic brands About million teens are smokers and sconsume nearly billion packs year. Seventy percent of teen smokers become regular smokers by age 18_ Eriksen said teens are more vulnerable to advertising by the [Obacco industry_ with its images of independent, social_ and sophisticated people who also smoke. Tobacco companies S4.6 billion ear in advertising and promotions but insist don't target children: They do support campaigns t0 discourage children smoking- most notably spending hundreds of thousands of dollars tO print placards warning teen-agers that buying cigarettes is illegal. Just as you don t blame General Motors for children who steal cars nor should you say cigarette brands initiate kids smoking_ said Thomas Lauria; spokesman for the Tobacco Institute industry group_ He pointed t0 the June decision by the Federal Trade Commission to end an investigation of the Joe Camel campaign without complaint; The FTC said at the time that it lacked evidence to support allegations that the campaign encourages children t0 smoke_ FTC spokeswoman Bonnie Jansen said that the information used in the decision not made public and could not say whether the commission was aware of the CDC repor: The report was based on a 1993 survey of 702 smokers ages 12-18 whose brand preference was known_ Marlboro was the most popular cigarette, accounting for 60 percent of teen sales; while Camel and Newport each about 13 percent of the teen market: Marlboro was also the most popular cigarette overall, with 23.5 percent markel Share_ according to the CDC. That same Marlboro, Camel and ranked second and third in advertising expenditures; Marlboro_ made by Philip Mordivenlioie Dos cleariliotord Orecisick cigarettes In /989, L year after the smooth character' of the cartoon Joe Camel was fun whiie Diego; they spend they fron filing grabbed Newport first; Year;
Text Adam: GA CDC-Smoking-Teens, 740 Smoking Teens Respond to Cigarette Advertising ATLANTA (AP) "Tbe three most heavily advertised cigaretie brands_ depicted by Joe Camel, the Marlboro Man and the fun couples of Newport. captured 86 percent of the tecn-age market while accounding for only 35 percent of overall sales, aecording to a new study released Thursday. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that based - on the data showing that advertising influences brand preference among teens, legislation may be needed to restriet cigarette adyertising, **The results are preity striking. We were shocked by the magnitude in the difference," said Michael Eriksen, director of the CDC's Office on Smoking and Health. "It shows that advertising not only works, but it works better for teens than adulis.* s it true? Absolutely," said John P. Pierce, head of the Cancer Prevention and Conteol Program at the University of. California, San Diego, Cancer Cenier in La Jolla. * What we're seeing here is, the kids are smoking only the brands ... with huge advertising campaigns, not the generic brands." „About 3 million teens are smokers and they sconsumme nearly 1 billion packs a year. Seventy percent of teen smokers become regular smokers by age 18. Briksen said teen$ are more vulnerable to advertising by the tobacco industry, with its images of independent, sacial, and - sophisticated people who also smoke. "Tobacco companies spend $4.6 billion a year in advertising and promotions, but insist hey dont target children. They do support campaigns to discourage children from smoking, most notabły spending hundreds of fhousands of dollars to print płacards warning teen-agers that buying cigaretes is illegal. Just as you don't bleme General Motors for children who steal carę, nor shiould you say cigarette brands initiate kids smoking," said Thomas Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry group. He polated to the June decision by the Federal Trade Commission to end an investigation of the Jae Camel campaign without filing a compłaint. The FTC said at the time that it Jacked evidence to support aliegations that the campaign encourages children to smoke. - FTC spokeswoman Bonnie Jansen said that the information used in the decision is not made public and could not say whether the eomumission was aware of the CDC report. - "The report was based on a 1993 survey of 702 smokecs ages 12-18 - włiose brand preference was known. Matlboro was the most popular Cigarette, accounting for 60 percent of teen sales, while Camel and Newport each grzbbed abont 13 percent of the teen market. Marlboro E was also the most popular cigarette overall, with a 23.5 percent dw market share, according to the CDC. KJ "That same year, Marlboro, Camel and Newport ranked first, second m and third in advertising expenditures, Marlboro, made by Philip "| Moris, alone spent $75 million on advertising. rej Advertising most clearly worked for Cartel cigarettes. In 1989, a s year afier the "smooth character” of the cartoon Joe Carel was 5 co CZ

The coppany saia North Anerican food operating reveniee rose - 2.5% to $21.6 billion despite the frozen-foods divestitures. Excluding thę aivestituras, revenuea were up 5.98, the conpany Gaia. Philip Morris Said North American iocd operating income rose 5.6% to $2.5 billion, driven by volune growth in a number of key. cztogęriec, cost inprovenents resulting from blsiness restructuring and higher returns from the coffee business. „The Company said Maxwell House volume was lower because of higher retail prices due to higher green bean costs, Philip Morris said its international food business posted operating income Gf $1.2 billion in 1994, up 3.5% from 1993, on revenieś of 510.1 biliion, ub 7.2$ from 1933. The company said the results, which were partially offset by unfavorable currency movements, reflect acquisitions and volume growth in confectionery, cheese and powdęred soft drinka. _ , Excluding Ehe effect Ó£ currency, Fhilip Morris said operating income for the year rose 5.54. Based on thc information received from Track Itl, total of 3,058 attempts were made by callers trying to receive tickets. The difference of 228 (7.5% of all attempts), Ieflects the number of call attempts made that could not get through because all lines were busy. Calls are broken down as follows (including rotary callers who were transferred directly to Neodata from the Network): 1998 1991 Total Calls Offered 3,058 7,108 Total Single Attempts ,668 4,806 Total Multiple Attempts 1,390 2,374 Total Multiple Callers 556 1,023 Total Number of Callers 2,224 2,783 On average, consumers who made multiple attempts, called 2 times 25% of callers made multiplc attempts and thosc multiple attempts accounted for 45% of total calls offered_ One caller made 12 multiple attempts to get through. 1 Covp Ml

Text Adam: . = 2) Ł ; ŚMĄET e PHILIP MORRIS U.S.A INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.t. 10027 To: Distribution Date: April 18, 1991 From: Rebecca Wallach Gordon | Subject: Switching Module Proposal OBJECTTYES As per our January 2, 1991 meeting in Chicago, attended by Kathy Lally, Jerry Isaacs, and Alejandro Lopez, the objectives of the proposed switching study are as follows: 1. To identify switchers -- their demographios and other common characteristics —- and determine their reasons for switching. II. "o identify what brand characteristics cause consumers to a switch. ex III. To gain a better understanding of the process switchers go (U b through before making a brana switch. s | ml” IV. To identify whether there is a period of time vhen switchers ! are vulnerable to switch again -- either to their old brand or CA to a new one. zć 44 ) Bv better understanding svitchers and the switching process, we hope to anticipate switching and target switchers so that they p A switch to, or remain with, a Philip Morris brand. „A JE ją DW g- uBrionorocy 2 o - - * The study should be conducted as a module which will be attached at the end of the our continuous tracking study. - The module will consist of two sets of questions, the first will be asked of switchers and the second of potential switchers. + Names and telephone numbers of respondents should be kept on file, so that they can be contacted at a later date —- as part of a longitudinal study -- to determine whether those respondents who are now identified as potential switchers actually switch and, if so, whether they switch back to their 5 original brand or switch to a new brand. 8 3 EJ s $

To identify switchers -- their demographios and other common characteristics —- and determine their reasons for switching. II. "o identify what brand characteristics cause consumers to a switch. ex III. To gain a better understanding of the process switchers go (U b through before making a brana switch. s | ml” IV. To identify whether there is a period of time vhen switchers ! are vulnerable to switch again -- either to their old brand or CA to a new one. zc 44 ) Bv better understanding svitchers and the switching process, we hope to anticipate switching and target switchers so that they p A switch to, or remain with, a Philip Morris brand. „A JE ja DW g- uBrionorocy 2 o - - * The study should be conducted as a module which will be attached at the end of the our continuous tracking study. - The module will consist of two sets of questions, the first will be asked of switchers and the second of potential switchers. + Names and telephone numbers of respondents should be kept on file, so that they can be contacted at a later date —- as part of a longitudinal study -- to determine whether those respondents who are now identified as potential switchers actually switch and, if so, whether they switch back to their 5 original brand or switch to a new brand. 8 3 EJ s $

H_ Daniel Date: September 16, 1975 Fron; Anne F Cantile Subject: History of Mailout Tests (HTI, POL) Involving Plastic Filters vs. CA Filters SUMMARY: If there is a consumer perceived benefit to the plastic would be its ellectiveness. The majority of panel tests run uSing this filter versus a CA filter find the plastic filter cigarette to be milder and too weak  Nevertheless, the plastic filter is judged to be the more effective filter and equally acceptable in appearance to the CA_ I is this _mildness_and effectiveness, in particular_ that appear to be the positive attributes Which make a cigarette with a plastic filter more appealing to the hi-fi smoker group than the full-flevored smoker group. In a POL Multifilter Image test conducted in 1972, Multifilter was rated equally with Marlboro on attractiveness of filter but higher than Marlboro on effectiveness of filter Multifilter was reportedly perceived aS being low in tar _ Thus, the data would seem to indicate that although the consumer finds the appearance of_the_plastic filter_equally acceptable to the CA filter, nonetheless, equates JOl flavor and mildness with this filter which may or may not determine his brand choice - AFC:fs A{ltt Attachment cc: Goldsmith McDowell Wakeham R. Seligman Resnik K: foongon 1 Johnston filter, he,

"WASHINGTON, DG 20008 Vie Praldont 202/42-4000* 004424.908 Spel Freja MEMORANDUM / December 6, 1991 TO: Kurt Malmgren FROM: — Hob MeAdam Ez £ LE 7 SUBJECT: Massachusetts Tax Initiattye Qn Thurday, December 5, 1991, the Massachusetts Director of Elections issued a leiter to the proponenis indieating that ie would transmit the initiative petiiion to the Clerk of the House of IRepresentatives following their submission of 108,358 valid signatures allowed under the cotnty distribution rule. T have attached a copy of the letter for your information, There ara three methods by which we could attempt to raducz the number of valid signatures during the next thirty dzys. First, we could attempt to identify forged signatures through the use of a handwriting expert. Second, we could attempt to identity mistakes | made in the verificatlon pracess by the county clerks. Third, we could attempt to identify individuals who signed the petition in error and ask them to withdraw their signature, Jes my opinton that the sum total of these approaches will not yield anywhere near the spproxima:ely 38,000 signatures that would be necessary to disqualify this initiative, Therefore, I do recommend that we not attempt to challenge the validity of the signatures. Our next step in this area ja to file a case in tha Sugreme Judioial Cowt alleging the uneonstltutlonality of the initiative based on Azticle 48 of the Massachusetts Constitutlon, | which prokibits initlatives from appropriatlng sund, It is unlikely that a resolution of that case cynid be achisyed before March or April. | Jn the meantime, we must pursne this issue as it will be considered in the legislature beginning in January, Please let me know if you have any questions. G]ycoside Ester Patent and Project . Some time ago I suggested to Eric Rundberg the pos- sibility of using sugar glycosides as pyrolytie precursors 8 2 .. for the generation of alcoholic flavorants. In addition,  - a further applicatiom of such a concept was discussed; - * namely, the use of 1,l-dimethylalliy! B-B-glucopyranoside as an isoprene release agent wia pyrolytic formation of 1,1- dimethyłally! alcohol followed by therma] dehydration. The -. synthesis of 1,l-dimethylallyl 2,3,4,6-tetra-0-acetyl-g-0- - glucopyranoside was carried Out successfully. Before this *.s compound was converted to.the deacetyjated glycoside, however, FZ -..; jtowas pyrołyzed in order: to ascertain whether any isoprene RS was indeed released. ln actuality no Isoprene was detected: 2 *;'0m'the.other hand a large amount Of acetic acid was noted. | - Lid - Since Flavor Development has expressed interest in acetic A acid-release compoinds for some time, the idea occurred to ; Eric that'such a compound might be useful despite the fact that isoprene was not. formed. „A sample of the acetylated głycoside was delivered to Frank Crayton who injected it into a Harlboro and placed the - treated cigareńtes on the SEF panel. The cigarette with the acety]ated glycoside proved to be less "spicy" at. the 0.0: = probability level and was preferred overall at the 0.12 probaż bility level. (See Booth Test Data Summary Sheet, tarch 18, 1976.) It was originally assumed that the subjective improve- ment noted in the panel test was due to either acetic acid or 2-methyl-2-butene - the pyrołysis product from the aglycone - or a combination of the two compounds. As a consequence, we sent some D-glucosepentaacetate to Flavor Development for evaluatiom. The effect. of the fully acetylated Sugar was h completely negative. =) -) The next development was a result of the observation of © Bi11 Johnson that the amounts of acetic acid or 2-nethyl-2- py butene which could be delivered to mainstream Snoke were too  (Q small to rationalize the subjective effect; and the discovery Ń of a patent which disclosed the use of peresterified sugars a as acid-release compounds. in tobacco, (See Ashburn, U.Ś. |-IOE sa 2,766,146.) I suggested to Eric that the project be temporć » = zob Fjetj arily abandoned until we couid design experiments which woułd | „4 2; give us some indication of exaętly what was going on. Eric, WONI either despite of or because of my comments, proceeded with the tx an ZNOW ZONEP SZ O PEDCCNNI ONE

INBIFO Koeln 10001 HHAETS1216_ESTDOC 3U.Mz.94 DATE 90 2. 7934 HHM @ WST, KBE, PKU, SGE, DKU, WGK, WSL, CRC, ERO Betr : Protokoll des MM vomQ9 Mrz.94: Mogllchkeit der Verwendung 'positiver Kontrollen' bel der Etabllerung der 'intermediate end polnts  ~ Je nach Stand der Etabllerung der verschiedenen Assays konnen positive Kon- trollen verschiedene Zwecke erullen: Falls   bisher im Lauf der Mathoden- etablierung noch kein Etfekt gesehen werden konnte oder auch kein Etfekt In den RASS-Studien erwartet wird, soll die Ansprechbarkelt des Tests gezeigt werden: Falls ein Effekt erwartet wird, konnte mit der  positiven Kontrolle der Vollausschlag ermittelt werden: Wenn es Lm qualitativ unterschiedliche Muster geht, konnen durch  verschiedene positive Kontrollen evantuollverschledeno Muster  erzeugt werden: Fellg moglich eine  eigene keine Carclno- genitatsstudie als positive Kontrolle durchzuidhren, konnte der Zeitverlauf des Auftretens der intermadiate markers Im Vergleich zu dem der Tumorentwicklung ermittelt werden; Insgesamt konnen solche Studien auch dazu dlenen, die Rele- vanz der end points zu bewerten FOr die verschiedenen beteiligten Teams ergaben sich auch verschiedene WOn- sche bezuglich positiver Kontrollen: MO und CB2 sind an Ratten-Tumorgewebe oder zeitlichen Vorlaufern interes- siert: Wir haben bereits Kontakt zum Zentralinstitut in Hannover und zu Prof. Grimmer in GroBhansdorf autgenommen und um Archivmaterial gebeten: Dieases Material hatte den Vorteil  berelts histologisch typifiziert zu sein: Grimmer hatte Ende der 8Oer Jahre die Tumorentwicklung ber Ratten untersucht, denen Kon- densate von SS; (sic) und B(a)p Bienenwachs  implantiert  worden waren; Wir werden in den nachsten Tagen sehen, wie kooperativ belde Instituto sind: Fur BC kamen 3 Moglichkeiten in Frage: Eine akute Behandlung von Ratten mit Paraquat (Redox-Cycler) (bei CAC): datur ist bisher allerdings keine 8-OH-dG- Bildung sondern nur Lipidperoxidation gezeigt worden. Eine akute Inhalation von Ratten mit hohen FSS-Konzentration (2.B_ 100 pg TPM; Tage; bel CRC): diese Behandlung Ist nicht sicher als positiv einzustufen' Beschattung von Material von strahlen-behandelten Ratten von der KFA Karlsruhe Fur PY_(die ersten BrdU-angefarbten Schnitte aus Nase und Darm liegen vor) und CB2 (spezifisches Cytokeratin-Muster) ist eine akute FSS-Inhalation ebenso nutzlich wie fur BC_ I DEE elner

Text ING: ZHILIPMQRRIS USA WNTER QEFICE CQRRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE; NEW YCRK NY 10017-5592 To: Distribution DATE: 13, 1991 FROM: Marketing Iniormation & Analysis Ellen Fitzgerald SUBJECT: EULLMARGIN CQMPETITIE CQUPON ACTIITY Attached is the latest competitive supermarket coupon information (through March 24, 1991) as reported by various data sources Note:  Media-delivered coupor information as repored by the Adverising Checking Bureau is currently available through February. SUMMARY RJR reduced the overall level of coupon support behind their Full Margin brands_ This shift was driven by reductions in on-cartonin-store couponing Philip Morris' Full Margin couponing increased versus year-ago due t0 the various Fourth Quarer 1990 Direct Mail programs for Marlboro Merit and Benson & Hedges Lorillard significantly increased coupon support behind Newport, Kent and True Importantly, this higher value coupon activity has had positive impact on the brands' share performance in the supermarket trade lass (as reported by the InfoScan Rapid Fact data base): In addition, Lorillard is using new coupon delivery system: Register Receipt Coupons which delivers $5.00 coupons for Newport to consumers at retail: American and Brown & Williamson are focusing their couponing efforts behind their Price Value/Sub-Generic brands and have consequently reduced support for the manufacturers' Full Margin businesses HGHLIGHTS Supermarket Full Margin ccuponing trends continue t0 be driven primarily by RJJ. Reynolds (4O% of volume sold on coupon) and Lorillara's recent emphasis benind their Full Margin brands 37%2 Of volume) for the four-week period ending March 24tn However, note_tnat RJR"s Full Margin couponing has ost momentum auring First Quarer 1991, Full Margin's percent volume sold on coupon for the manulacturer is down from high of 51% at the end of 990 t0 its current level cf 40%. Price Value couponing for RJJ; Reynolds remained stable at around 62% during First Quarter 991_ Couponing for RJR's Full Margin brands declined primarily as result of decreasing in-storelon-carton coupon activity_ For the most current four-week period, the percent %i stores with on-carton couponing for Winston decreased -24 points to 4% versus the prior period; Salem, 27 points to 16%; Camel, -27 points to 7%; and Vantage, 224 points to 89. With the exception of Camel however; Full Margin coupon activity (supported by media-delivered programs for Winston (42% Of volume sold on coupon), Salem (45% and Vantage remained high relative t0 the industry average_ Camel 1 experienced significant decline in volume sold on coupon 6 points t0 only 19%) due in part to reductions after the introductory support behind Ultra Lights Additionally, it is likely that RJR is reducing the level of in-storelon-carton couponing behind the brand t0 refocus support t0 Camel on pack sales in Convenience Outlets, May nlng

Text ING: Ek (ax PHILIP MORRIS MANAGEMENT CORP. INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 120 PARK AVENUE NEW YORK, NY 10017-5592 TO: Mr: Colin Goddard DATE: September 25, 1996 Dr. Roger Walk Mr: Eric Windholz FROM: Matthew N. Winokun RE: Draft FTS Communication; Resource _Book Ihave enclosed revised edition of the Message Point section of the draft ETS Communications Resource Book: Given all of the edits to both the first and second drafts which have been requested; it seemed only fair to try to incorporate those comments and others provided subsequently and offer you an amended version, harmonizing all the recommendations, for your consideration_ Wherever possiblc the revised edition adheres to the spirit and lettcr of the original. Following some of the structural changes: A new opening "Overview" sequence of messages is suggested using those already cited throughout the document: These are placed at the beginning to offer top line messages which may be supported in subsequent sections_ References t0 exposure study research has been moved up to the Overview section as have the other arguments which seem related to the underlying weaknesses of the ETS science You I note that references to personal monitoring studies' have been deleted. [t seems technical point to explain how the actual exposure data are Obtained and white paper is available elsewhere in the binder to elaborate The section on respiratory effects has been consolidated, providing One for alleged effects on adults and another for alleged effects on children: And the asthma arguments which were previously third section are now placed under the adult and children sections: The original Science and Public Policy section remains unchanged But an alternative version i5 suggested at the conclusion: The title suggests discussion about the broader issue of how science in general, not just FTS, and public policy interact rather than further discussion about how ETS science should be evaluated more carefully by scientists and policy makers_ The former is 1 bigger debate and_ because of it, we have the opportunity to position ETS in the context of larger issue to due with sound science, reversals in scientific opinion and unnecessary regulation the

Yow'l note that references ta "personal monitoring studies" have been deleted, I seemns a technical point to explain how the actual exposure data are obiained, and a white paper is available elsewhere in tie binder to elaborate. + The section on respiratory effects has been consolidated, providing one for alleged effacts on adults and another for alleged effects on children. Text Adam: Environment and Human Health PARTB by Dietrich Henschler (University of Wirzburg) I. Imtreduction: Environmental risk factors - new and old Health hazards and risks have accompanied mankind Źram its very beginning. One may roughly categorize these factors into - living organisus (bacteria, viruses, higher parasites) - physical (mechanical, thermal, acoustic, radiological) - chemical. . Medicine responded to these challenges at an early date by systenatizing efforts to diagnosa, cure and prevent diseases induced by the first two groups of factors and forming special subdisciplines, particularly for research: e.g. microbiology, virology, parasitology, special sectors of surgery, and (more recently) radiobialogy. Now these disciplines are proud oś their rich tradition. Accordingly, the principal strategies of treatment and prophylaxis of damage caused by these environmental exposures are wall established. Epidemiology, for sxample, evolved from research on the spread of infectious diseases ained at the elaboration of effective measures of prevention and developed principles which are;st11 operative in environmental epideniology today. Y gi In contrast, in the past chemical ZA factors dia not fina the same recognition by medical sciggie! There were some eariy ©bservations of chemically iągóżEa disease resulting from acute overexposure to sone noziagPenenicals, and suicide and homicide by poisoning have indeed a very long history. However, the "silent" type of exposure to environmental chemicals as is understood in our present concept of environnentally induced a health effects has only recently been recognized as deserving a © scientific enterprise of its own. For this reason, and because 5 chemicals play a predominant role in the present-day discussion ©Ż Of environmentally induced ailments, this paper will EJ <oncencrate on the analysis of chemical hazards and risks, and try to describe their impact on health politics and to identify

Text ING: August 1995 CONTACT: (212) 907-5830 For IMMEDIATE RELEASE PHILIP_MORRIS USA IQDAY_ISSUED_THE FQLLQWING_STATEMENI: Today Philip Morris U.S.A. joined the four other major U.S. cigarette manufacturers and an advertising firm in filing suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina in order to the Food and Drug Administration from proceeding on course of action that clearly is illegal. Philip Morris U.S.A: is the domestic tobacco subsidiary of Philip Morris Companies Inc. The follows FDA Commissioner David Kessler's release of proposed regulations governing cigarettes_ The regulations are based on President Clinton's decision to allow FDA to assert jurisdiction over cigarettes under federal law that gives him power to regulate medicines_ medical devices pharmaceutical products. The purported justification for FDA   regulations is to prevent minors from smoking: On the issue of youth smoking we share common goal with all Americans: minors should not smoke and should not have access to cigarettes We support number of steps both voluntary and legislative, that will make real difference on this issue_ We will fight against the that the FDA is the right way to make difference on youth smoking: We will fight as vigorously for our alternative program, which combines state level regulation and enforcement with voluntary efforts to make real impact on this critical socia issue_ Having opted to pursue more federal regulation, the Administration has ensured that the more effective and expedient course of cooperative action takes second place to those who want to expand the federal bureaucracy and its unwanted intrusion into the private lives of adult Americans The Administration's decision is all the more troubling in light of the fact that Philip Morris, several weeks ago, committed itself to comprehensive program Action Against Access, designed to prevent kids from obtaining cigarettes by any legal means Once all the elements are implemented, the result WILL be retail 1 stop suit and idea just
Text Adam: ny NI U August 10, 1995 CONTACT: (212) 907-5830 FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE BHILIP MORRIS U.S.A. TODAY ISSUED THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT: Today Philip Mortis U.8.A. joined the four other major U.S, cigarette manufacturers and an advertising firm in fiing suit in the U.S. District Gourt for the Middle Distret of North Garolina in ordar to stop the Food and Drug Administration from proceeding on a course of action that cleady is illegal. Philip Moris U.S.A. is the domestic tobacco subsidiary of Philip Morris Companies Inc. Te suit follows FDA Commissioner David Kessler release of proposed regulations goveming cigarettes. The regulations are based on Presidant Gllnton's dacision to allow FDA to assert jutisdiction ovar cigarettes under a federal law that gives him power to regulate medicines, medical devices and pharmaceutical products. The purported justlilcation for FDA regulations is to prevent minors from smoking. On the Issue of youth smoking, we shara a common goal with all Americans: minors should not smoke and should not have access to cigarettes, We support a number of steps, both voluntary and legislative, that will make a real difference on this issue. We will fight against the idea that the FDA is the right way to make a difference on youth smoking. We will fight just as vigorously for our alternative program, which combines state level regulation and enforcement with voluntary efforts to make a real impact on this eritical social issue. Having opted to pursue more federal regulation, the Administration has ensured that the more effective and expedient course of cooperative action takes sacond place to those who want to expand the federal bureaucracy and its unwanted intrusion into the private lives of adult Americans, The Administration's decision is all the more troubling in light of the fact that Philip Moris, several weeks ago, commiited itself to a comprehensive program, Action Ę Against Access, designed to pravent kids from obtaining cigarettes by any legal 4 means. Once all the elements are implemented, the result WILL be a retail ca m kd ja = 1 w NN

Text ING: PHILIP MORRIS USA NEWS RELEASE Corporate Affairs 120 Park Avenue New York; New York 10017 (212) 880-S000 FAX (212) 907-5361 FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE CONTACT: Victor Han April 13,1994 (202) 637-1566 SIX MAJOR AMERICAN CIGARETTE COMPANIES RELEASE COMBINED INGREDIENTS LIST New York Philip Morris U.SA , along with the five other major American cigarette manufactures, today approved the release of the industry's combined list of ingredients added to tobacco in cigarettes manufactured and sold in the United States "The industry'$ decision to make this proprietary information publicly available to our consumers is in response to misleading allegations recently made about the nature of the ingredients used in our products; said Steven Parrish, senior vice president and general counsel for Philip Morris USA He said the six major American cigarette manufactures decided to voluntarily disclose the combined ingredients list to "demonstrate to our consumers that cigarette ingredients are similar to ingredients used in & wide variety of consumer products and are not harmful to smokers_ Parrish said that Philip Morris and the other five companies had been submitting list of ingredients added to tobacco used in cigarettes manufactured and sold in the United States to the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) as required by the Federal 8 Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act each year since 1986. The Act recognizes that cigarette ingredients are trade secrets and requires that HHS maintain strict confidentiality. 1 more MARLBORO BENSON HEDGES MERIT VIRGINIA SLIMS PARLIAMERT LIGHTS CAMBRIDGE ALPINE PLAYERS SARATOGA

Text Adam: Corporte Atfórs d 120 ask Areone "Rew Yosk, New York 10017 (212) 880-5000 FAX (12) 907-5361 For Immediate Release Contact: (212) 907-5331 (212) 907-5332 Philip Morris U.S.A. Announces Initiative Against Youth Smoking NEW YORK, June 27, 1995 -- Philip Momis U.S.A. today launched a new Initiative to attack the problem of yautn smoking. The program -- Action Against Access -- has been crealed to make it as difficult as possible for minors to purchase cigarettas. *The best way to keep kids away from cigarettes is to keep cigarettes away from kids," Philip Moris U.S.A. President and CEO James J. Morgan said, in announclng the program. It includes unilateral steps such as discontinuing free cigarette sampling to consumers and the distribution of Philip Morris cigarettes by mail. The Campany also announced that it will inelude a notice on its cartons and packs Indicating that the sale of cigarettes to minors is prohibited. In addition, tne Company indicated that it will withhold merchandising benefits from stores which are fined for or convicted of breaking minimum age laws. And Philip Moris U.S.A. will fund a major 8 retail compliance training program called "Ask First/lfs the Law” on how $ to ask for and verify proof of age for the purchase of cigarettes. EJ Ś a - more - MARLBORO _DESORA HEDOKS. MERA. YIRGTASIAKS.PARIJAMNTLONISCAMAAMGE. ALBRNE GLAYERS SARARGOA.

Announces Initiative Against Youth Smoking NEW YORK, June 27, 1995 -- Philip Momis U.S.A. today launched a new Initiative to attack the problem of yautn smoking. The program -- Action Against Access -- has been crealed to make it as difficult as possible for minors to purchase cigarettas. *The best way to keep kids away from cigarettes is to keep cigarettes away from kids," Philip Moris U.S.A. President and CEO James J. Morgan said, in announclng the program. And Philip Moris U.S.A. will fund a major 8 retail compliance training program called "Ask First/lfs the Law” on how $ to ask for and verify proof of age for the purchase of cigarettes. Text ING: DRAFT _ NOT FOR RELEASE FOR MMMEDIATE RELEASE Contact:  Scott Williams March [4, 1998 202/739-0225 Steve Duchesne 202/739-0245 TOBACCO INDUSTRY BEGENS ADVERTISING TO BUILD UNDERSTANDING OF COMPREHENSIVE RESOLUTION WASHINGTON,DC. The nation'$ leading cigarette companies today began advertising t0 inform the American people about the details of the comprehensive tobacco agreement negotiated last June between the industry, state attoreys general, private plaintiffs' lawyers and representatives of the public health community. "Despite all the media coverage since last June, the American people don't really the most significant details contained in this historic agreement said Steven C. Parrish; scnior vice president of the Philip Morris Companies: "When they learn the facts, we believe they will increasingly come to the view that the proposed resolution makes sense &nd will also make important immediate contributions to lowering youth smoking while protecting the rights of adults who use tobacco products  The ads, which have bcen timed t0 coincide with an acceleration of Congressional activity about the proposed resolution, will appear in newspapers and on television and radio stations around the country. The print &nd television ads contain nO visual images beyond the of the agreement negotiated last year. "This is & "just the facts' approach because the public needs to know the facts; said Mr. Parish Advertising offers the most effective way of providing the American pcople with the basic clements of the proposed resolution. "The advertising will also help clear up some misconceptions about the resolution, such the false assertion that the proposed resolution provides legal immunity for the companies Individuals can still sue the companics for actual damages and for punitive damages relating to future conduct  We think the public needs to know things like that in order t0 make an informed judgement about the resolution " more - 1 know and . details

Text ING: CCT 24 03:33FM CoFF FURCHFSING Pnc P.3/3 PHILIP MORRIS USA NEWS RELEASE Corporcte Affin 120 Pak Avenue New York New Yoik 0017 (212) 880-S000 FAX (2.2}907-5361 Contacl: Dolly 212.878-2144 STATEMENT BY PHILIP MORRIS U.SA_ October 18, 1995 Philip Morris U.S.A. today issued the following statement in response to today' story about ammonia in The Wall Street Joumal Ammonia is raturally present in tobacco Several ammonia compounds also are used In the cigarette manufacturing process as prccessing aids and flavcrants_ For example, Philip Morris U.SA, uses diammonium pncsphate (DAP) an ammonia-related compound, to hol tobacco pieces together when making one type of reconstituted tobacco sheet: Reconstituted tobacco has been used for over 25 years as pant of tne tobacco blend in cigarettes Phllip Morris USA_ also uses several ammonia compounds to give flavor or feel similar t0 what one feels in the throat from tne carbonation of soft drink, tne "hot" in peppers or the "cool feeling" of mint: Such use pf ammonia flavorants is not unique to Philip Morris U.S.A or the cigarette industry Ammonia compounds are used in variety of consumer products including beverages_ ice cream, ices; gelatin, puddings _ and baked goods_ Philip Morris U.S.A.'s use of ammonia compcunds has been public knowledge for many years_ manufacturing processes that utilize ammonia compounds have been described in published articles ard patents which were filed with the government Further; the tobacco industry Jist of ingredients submitted t0 the Department of Health and Human Services since 1986 inciudes the ammonia compounds used by Philip Morris U.S.A. Contrary to speculation in The Wall Street Joumal, Philip Morris U.SA does not use ammonia in the cigarette manufacturing procass to increase the amount of nicotine inhaled by the smoker or to "affect the rate of absorption of nicotine in t0 the bloodstream of the smoker; or to "increase the potency of the nicotine smoker actually inhales_ If, as The Wall Street Journal assers_ Philip Morris U.SA were using ammonia t0 increase nicotine deliveries of lower tar cigarettes one would expect that as tar and nicotine deliveries of Marlboro have failen over the past twenty years; ammonia levels would have increased: But that simply not tne case; over the past 25 years the amount of ammonia has remained nearly constant ' This , of course, is precisely the opposite of what one would expect it,as The Wall Street Joumal arid others have charged, Philip 8 Morris U,S,A_ were using ammonia to enhance nicotine delivery to smckers_ 1 Colby chili Those

KORNEGAY President, The Tobacco Institute at the 19th Annual Meeting Tobacco Growers Information Committee Qctober 14, 1377 Raleigh M.O. *  Much has been said about tobacco...pro and con...but one thing is for - sure. Tobacco causes conttoversy.  It has a wnique capacity to please a great many people and to provoke a few,  Tobacco has always been valued and vilified. It is popular with the multitude...and condemned by the elite. It is enjoyed by millions OE coa- sumers...and sniped at by self-appointed consumer activists.  But despite all the controversy they have generated, the antismoking i lobhy has never been abie to win a decisive victory over the popular practice  8 of tobacco smoking. Ten and twenty times a day, sixty million Aiericans vote "No" to the propagandists who exhort them to quit suoking.  Uażortunately, the defendets of tobacco, wbich is America's oldest industry, are none too vocal in response to the critics. Neither are those who depend on tobacco for theżr economic health and well-being. The burning question is how long tobacco can continue to hold out, How long can our rełative silence offset their strident attacks?  My friends, noue of us here today could conceive of an Anerica without a tobaceo industry. But there are those in our gociety for whom the end of the Ę wobacco Sndustey 20 we koś dt 18 not unthintable. And they are gatałog tn strength by default. True, their arguments are just as weak as they ever Ż were...but thotr volume and vdsibility is much higher. Their logic is just as poor aa it ever was...but it gains credibility by being largely unchallenged.

Text ING: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE CONTACT: John Lenzi 15, 1995 212-880-4119 PHILIP MorrIS APPLAUDS RULING ALLOWING CASTANO APPEAL Philip Morris is very pleased by ruling today issued by U.S: District Judge Okla Jones in the Castano class action case in New Orleans   Judge Jones granted motion filed by Philip Morris and the other defendants to allow them to pursue an immediate appeal to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals of his decision to certify certain common issues for class handling: Charles Wall, senior vice president and associate general counsel at Philip Morris, applauded the decision, saying it was the common-sense way to manage the litigation. "This case presents many important legal issues that will inevitably be decided by the Fifth Circuit, and makes sense to have these issues decided now, before both sides embark on lengthy and costly proceedings and preparation_ Wall said: Judge Jones also granted the defendants' motion to stay all proceedings in the trial court until the Fifth Circuit has ruled on the issue of class certification: The companies believe that certification was improper in part; because individual issues predominate _ Philip Morris and the other defendants now plan to ask the Fifth Circuit to decertify the Castano class:  May pretrial

Text ING: OBJECTIVE Evaluate the collection efficiency of the Cambridge filter (CF) specified as the smoke collection device by the FTC nicotine method Determine effect; if any, of the ammonia level of the filler or smoke on the amount of nicotine on second collection device used in the evaluation of CF collection efficiency Message Points for this slide: Two purposes for these studies ~The first was an investigation of the nicotine collection efficiency of the FTC method, using a trap after the Cambridge filter to collect any nicotine which was not retained by the CF. 'The second purpose was to compare collection efficiencies for cigarettes 1 with varying filler and mainstream ammonia levels.

the CRS concluded: Mid-range estimates based upon likely assumptions suggest net external costs from smoking in the range of 33 cents per pack in 1995 prices an amount that by itself is too small to justify either current cigarette taxes (averaging 50 cents per pack) or the proposed tax increase. Text Adam: The Tobacco Institute 1875 1 Street, Northwest I Waskington, DO 20006 " (800) 424-9876 FOR RELEASE: CONTACT: June 23, 1994 Media Relations Upon Receipt 202/457-9387 Federal Keports Indicate Smokers Fay Their Own Way -- And Then Sone Washington, DC -- Smokers already make enormous contributions to government health care financing — in excise and sales taxes, personal income and Social Security taxes and other fees. ln fact, smokers appear already to be subsidizing nonsmokers in these programs, not the Other way around. | Recently published economic analyses from the Congressional Office of Technology 3 Assessment (OTA) and the Congressional Research Service (CRS) conciude that the excize taxes paid by smokers exceed the "costs" of federal, state and local govermment | funding of health care expenditures attributed to smokingrrelated illnesses. i In a report releżsed in May 1993, the OTA estimated that smokers "cost" federal, state | and local governmenis $8.9 billion in health care expenditures because Of s illnesses viewed as "smoking-related;" Assuming the validity of that NEWS RELEASE _ estimate for the sake of discussion, smokers currently pay federal, state n and local governments $11.3 billion in cigarette excise taxes and another $2 bilion in | sales taxes. The total tax collection of $13.3 billion is a tax that only smokers pay. : Thus, the OTA data indicates that smokers currently pay $4,4 billion more j to federal state and local governments than the 58. billion that OTA claims smokers "cost" all levels of government. The OTA further estimates the federal goverument's share of these governments" "costs" | at $63 billion. "This translates to $.24 per pack of cigarettes sold -- the current level of | the federal excise tax om cigarettes, : | Underscoring the OTA estimates are newly released data from the Congressional : Research Service. ln its March 1994 report to Congress, the CRS concłuded: "Mid-range estimates based upon likeły assumptions suggest net external costs from smoking in the range of 33 cents per pack in 1995 prices, an amount that by itself is too small to justify either current cigarette taxes (averaging 50 cents per pack) or the proposed tax increase." . a In February 1993 the American Medical Association (AMA) estimated that the U.S. 3 Government spent $4.2 billion in the Medicaid and Medicare programs on so-called |, £ "tobacco related illnesses." The AMA's data on federal spending again suggests that | Ń smokers are more than paying their own way. WR ee i czowe

Text ING: Ohio Retail Merchants Oppose Proposed FDA Rules On Tobacco Products COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. IPRNewswire' The Ohio Council of Retail Merchants today said the Food and Drug Administration (FDA's} attempt t0 regulate tobacco products Is serious distcrtion of the FDA's role and an unnecessary intrusion into private business and the SpbAof of citizens. The statements came as Iha public comment period on the proposed regulations ended today: Dale Masten_ Public Affairs Director for the Ohio Council of Retail Merchants said The FDA has no more business trying to regulate tobacco than it does coffeo or cola drinks FDA's proposed regulations are anather federal government intrusion into the lives of Americans_ The stated purpose of FDA's proposal to help limit youth access to tobacco. But, Masten pointed out his group already is working on Jislation in Ohio which for the would make it for minors to buy cigarettes in the same way as it is now for merchants lo sell to minors_ Tne Councils goal is to reduce youth access to tobacco products and House Bill 299 will help accomplish this goal,' Masten "The should concentrate on its mission of ensuring the purity of food and drugs_ and leave enforcement of tobacco purchase rules to and state enforcers, He added, "Any rules the FDA hands down undoubtodly will also make much mcre difficult for Americans to exercise their right to buy legal product; The Ohio Retail Merchants have joined with coalition of business leaders support Ohio House Bill 299. The bill establishes penaltios for the purchase of tobacco products by youths and strengthens penalties for those who sell tobacco producis t0 minors_ "Merchants have taken an active role in trying to prevent minors acquiring tobacco products_ We believe House Bill 299 will be much more effective in accomplishing this goal than more federal intervention, Masten said ICONTACT: Dale Masten of the Ohio Council of Retail Merchants 614-221- 7833/ Copyright (c) 1996 PR Newswire Received by NewsEDGEJLAN: 1/2/96 4,24 PM  legi first time illegal illega: FDA said ocal from
Text Adam: © Ohio Retail Merchants Oppose Proposed FDA Rules On Tobacco Products COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2 /PRNewswire/ -- Tha Ohio Council ot Retail Merchants today said the Food and Drug Administration (FDA!s) atternpt to regulate tobacco products is a serious distortion of tha FDA's rola and an unnecessary intrusioń into private business and the rights oł citizens, The staterents came 28 the public comrnent perlod or the FDA's proposed regulations ended taday. Dale Masten, Public Affafrs Diractor for the Ohio Council of Rtait Marchanis, sald, "The FDA has no mora business trying to regulate tobacco than It does cofiee or cola drinks. FDA's proposed regulatlons are another federal government intrusion into the lives of Americans." The statad purpose of FDA's proposal is to help limit youth access to tobacco. But, Masten polnted out hls group already |s working on legislation in Ohio syhich for th first time would make i illegal for minors to buy cigaraltes in the same way as itisillegał now for merchanis to sell to minors. "The Gounell's goal ls to reduce youth access to tobacco products and House Bill 258 will help accomplish this goal," Masten said, "The FDA should concentrate on Its mission of ensuring the purity of food and druge, and leave gnforcement of tobacco purchase rules to local and state enforcers." He added, "Any rules tho FDA hands down undoubtedły wl also make it much rnora difticult e for Americans to exercise their right to buy a legal product." The Ohio Retail Merchants have joined with a coalition of business Jeaders to support Ohio House Bill 298. The bill establishes penaliies for the purchase of tobacco products by youths and strengihens penaltias for those who sell tobacco products to minors, "Merchants have taken an aciive role in trying to prevent minors from acqulring tobacco products, We believe House Bill 298 wili be much more effective in accomplishing this goal than more federal intervention," Masten sald. /OONTACT: Dale Masten of the Ohio Council ot Retail Merchants, 614-221- 78837 Copyright (e) 1986 PR Newswira Fecelved by NewsEDGEJLAN: 1/2/08 4:24 PM >» 2 4 s sm © W - » je
Text Adam pl: © Ohio Retail Merchants Oppose Proposed FDA Rules On Tobacco Products COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2 /PRNewswire/ -- Tha Ohio Council ot Retail Merchants today said the Food and Drug Administration (FDA!s) atternpt to regulate tobacco products is a serious distortion of tha FDA's rola and an unnecessary intrusioń into private business and the rights ol citizens, The staterents came 28 the public comrnent perlod or the FDA's proposed regulations ended taday. Dale Masten, Public Affafrs Diractor for the Ohio Council of Rtait Marchanis, sald, "The FDA has no mora business trying to regulate tobacco than It does cofiee or cola drinks. FDA's proposed regulatlons are another federal government intrusion into the lives of Americans." The statad purpose of FDA's proposal is to help limit youth access to tobacco. But, Masten polnted out hls group already |s working on legislation in Ohio syhich for th first time would make i illegal for minors to buy cigaraltes in the same way as itisillegal now for merchanis to sell to minors. "The Gounell's goal ls to reduce youth access to tobacco products and House Bill 258 will help accomplish this goal," Masten said, "The FDA should concentrate on Its mission of ensuring the purity of food and druge, and leave gnforcement of tobacco purchase rules to local and state enforcers." He added, "Any rules tho FDA hands down undoubtedly wl also make it much rnora difticult e for Americans to exercise their right to buy a legal product." The Ohio Retail Merchants have joined with a coalition of business Jeaders to support Ohio House Bill 298. The bill establishes penaliies for the purchase of tobacco products by youths and strengihens penaltias for those who sell tobacco products to minors, "Merchants have taken an aciive role in trying to prevent minors from acqulring tobacco products, We believe House Bill 298 wili be much more effective in accomplishing this goal than more federal intervention," Masten sald. /OONTACT: Dale Masten of the Ohio Council ot Retail Merchants, 614-221- 78837 Copyright (e) 1986 PR Newswira Fecelved by NewsEDGEJLAN: 1/2/08 4:24 PM >» 2 4 s sm © W - » je

Text Adam: Fr  July 28, 1975  Mr. BILL Osterieln  4575 Bastern Avenue  Cincinnati, Ohio 45226  Dear BILL: "  Attached are a few memos and letters to printing companies  which wa have workęd with on printed media in the past, These  are security procedures which are very basic, soma would  relate to Gift Star coupon printing, Others will not. Two  major areas of concern in regard to Multicolor are your  destruction procedures and your receiving procedures.  Destruction - Under no circumstances should anyone from  Multicolor leave coupons intact in the hands of the person  that has to dastroy them. They must physically see the  destruction. -  Receiving - If you require all rejected coupons sent back  to you, there must be a tię of cartoń counts received with  bill of lading from the shipper.  Ń Please sce that the necessary procedures are carricd out  to control the medla so that we don't have tha problems  occur again. Text ING: March 22 , 1990 TO : Yancey Ford FROH: Doten SUBJECT: SHITCHING This is in response to brief conversation we had last Friday on the subj- of switching rates by age group _ There are several ways to define swi tching_ but B.I.D. strict definition probably the safest one to use It says switching has occurred When 90} or more the cigarettes smoker smokes are of brand that is different from the brand they used to smoke 908 of the time This definition was used in study of the purchases of several thousand smokers over six month period. The study showed that switching rates are highest in the 18 - 24 and 50+ age groups Percent of Smokers Age Switching Brands 18-24 18 25-34 35-49 50+ Switching rates are highest in these two groups for various reasons: Adult smokers aged 18-24 are still forming behavior patterns and developing preferences The 50+ age group is affected by costs (due to fixed incomes) and health concerns Many of these smokers switch lower price cigarettes and low cigarettes These results suggest that the greatest opportunity to convert competitive smoker are with the 18-24 and 50+ age groups The primary thrust of in-store trial opportunities should be with outlets Where there are relatively large con- centrations of these groups 8 3 ect tar
Text Adam: , March 22, 1990 To: Yancey Ford FROM: W. W. Doten SUBJECT: SWIDCHING i This is in response to a brief conversation we had last Friday on the subject of switching rates by age group. There are several ways to define switching, but B.I.D.'s strict definition is probably the safest one to use. It says switching has occurred when 90% or more of the cigarettes a smoker smokes are of a brand that is different from the brand they used to smoke 80% of the time. This definition was used in a study of the purchases of several thousand smokers over a six month period. The study showed that switching rates are highest in the 18- 24 and 50+ age groups. Percent of Snokers l Age Switching_Brands 18-24 4.13% 25-34 2.7 35-49 3.0 | 50+ 4.4 switching rates are highest in these two groups for various reasons: i » Adult smokers aged 18-24 are still forming behavior patterns and developing preferences. * The 50+ age group is affected by costs (due to fixed incomes) and health concerns. Many of these smokers switch to lower price cigarettes and low tar cigarettes. | These results suggest that the greatest opportunity to convert a competitive smoker are with the 18-24 and 50+ age groups. The primary thrust of in-store trial opportunities Should be with outlets where there are relatively large con- centrations of these groups. a | 8 | 3 8 u ej p) a |
Text Adam pl: , March 22, 1990 To: Yancey Ford FROM: W. W. Doten SUBJECT: SWIDCHING i This is in response to a brief conversation we had last Friday on the subject of switching rates by age group. There are several ways to define switching, but B.I.D.'s strict definition is probably the safest one to use. It says switching has occurred when 90% or more of the cigarettes a smoker smokes are of a brand that is different from the brand they used to smoke 80% of the time. This definition was used in a study of the purchases of several thousand smokers over a six month period. The study showed that switching rates are highest in the 18- 24 and 50+ age groups. Percent of Snokers l Age Switching_Brands 18-24 4.13% 25-34 2.7 35-49 3.0 | 50+ 4.4 switching rates are highest in these two groups for various reasons: i » Adult smokers aged 18-24 are still forming behavior patterns and developing preferences. * The 50+ age group is affected by costs (due to fixed incomes) and health concerns. Many of these smokers switch to lower price cigarettes and low tar cigarettes. | These results suggest that the greatest opportunity to convert a competitive smoker are with the 18-24 and 50+ age groups. The primary thrust of in-store trial opportunities Should be with outlets where there are relatively large con- centrations of these groups. a | 8 | 3 8 u ej p) a |

Extensive research conducted outside NIST has indicated that the test methods proposed by NIST rely 0n materials and conditions which produce results that are not representative of what happens in real-world settings resull serious questions have been raised abou: whether siandard bascd Ou thc NIST research may ultimately do more harm than good_ Since the federal government'$ work on this issue began the number of fire deaths attibuted [0 careless smoking has dropped by almost 60 percent Greater uSc of smoke detectors and spnnklers, fire education, improved building materials and flammability standards for home furnishings have contributed this substantial 1 reduction The effectiveness of these and other fire safety measures have been demonstrated in Other industialized nations_ all of which have dramatically lower rates of fires and fire deaths than the United States for reasons that have nothing t0 do with how their cigarettes are designed. Aubrey Thacker, Jr. This essential oil study (E0S) of KCPS has been completed and a table of results is attached. Most EOS components were identiFied by GC/S while a few were identified solely by gas chromatographie retention times. A. _Cased vs Untreśted" KCPS " Conpared with untreated KCPS, cased KCPS essentia oil has inereased . anountż of carbohydrate degradation products, neophytadiene, 2-acetylpyrrola, 4-vinylpłieno1, guaiacol, indole, myristie and palmitic acids. These increases may be explained by heat degradation of certain unknown tobacco compounds during drying of cased KCPS. " Conpounds Towóred by casing are pyrrole, 2- and 3-nethylbutyric acids, hexanoic acid, 3-acetylpyridine, f-nicotyrine, 2,3'-bipyridine, ką, kg, benzył alcohol, and Ż-phenylethanol. ecreases of these essentia1 oil conponents are due to a net reduction in tobacco weight per sample and Josses of volatile , compounds caused by the drying cycle after the casing operation. B. "Ammoniated-Cased vs Casćd_ KCPS m CENE Methylpyrazine and 2,6-dimethylpyrazine are found in the essential ot] of the armoniated product. These pyrazines are formed by the reaction of amonia with sugars present in the cased KCPS. Dther EOS conponents present in larger . anounts for the amnoniated-cased KCPS are 2» and 3-methylbutyrie actds, hexanoic - acid, neophyładtene, pyrrole-2-carboxyaldehyde, Kg, Kp, 4-vinylphenol, 2,3'-bipyridine, and g-nicotyrine. Compounds found in decreased anounis are carbohydrate degradation products, 3=isopropy1-6-va1erolactone, solanone, . oxysolanone, 4-hydroxydamascone, Vant1lin, 4-keto-a-ionol, myristie, penta- decanoic, and palmitic acids. Other EOS components found at higher Jevels in the treated sample are carbohydrate degradation products, neophytadiene, 2-acetyl- pyrrole, 4-vinylphenol, indole, myristic and palmitic acids. Apparentty amoniation is not abla żo conpensate fully for the rise in carbohydrate degradation products caused by casing. Text Adam: July 2, 1974  Mr, J. F, Hind:  Re: _ SALEM Back-Up Campaigns - Status |  MRD is preparing a written review of all campaigns tested from  both agencies with particular focus on the two campaigns which  we consider to be prime candidates for mini-market. It will be  available on Monday, July 8, and will include a discussion of  the points you raised in your June 28 memo to me. This written  analysis.wil] -serve-as-a-background review-for-oux meeting-with  you and Mr, Tucker on RSL campaigns at which MRD, the agency,  and the Brand Group will present our net analysis and recommendations.  |  Mt this time, we propose an agenda for the meeting which would  be roughły as Follows:  1. A brief review of the recently received results of MRD's segmentation study of SALEM and Kool and its implications for SALEM advertising. -  2. A brief review of what we have learned from SALEM's and WINSTON'S portfolio testing over the past year.  3. A discussion of two specific campaigns, including key research results, creative refinement of them, and a review of specific strategic and executional questions attendant to the analysis of these campaigns.  4. Mini-market objectives, research, eto.  We are now in the process of putting the meeting together. The  agency and MRD are doing extensive analytical ana creative work.  As a result, we would like to schedule the meeting for July 17 or  18. Would you please confirm with Mr. Tucker and let me know the  best day of the two,  DZE ŻĘ nins  DAC:1n  co: Mr. L. W. Text Adam: [Date]  Name Addrese Address Dear Name:  The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (osun) ie currently considering workplace smoking regulations that, iE enacted, would virtually ban smoking at all indopr worksiteg -- including Philiv Morris U.S.A.  Under thia proposal, employers would only be able to accomnadate smokers i£ they conetructed separate smoking xooms with completely separate ventilation systems. Advocates of these new rules are well aware that most employers cannot afford to provide geparately ventilated smoking rooms, and that the proposed rules actually constitute a nationwide workplace amoking ban.  Bven more troubling, OSHA's definition OE "workplace" is so broad it encompasses almost any indoor Location where an employee is present -- including your own home if you employ a plumber to fix your sink.  Othar 'workplaces" where smoking would be banned include all restaurants, bars, hotel rooms, private offices and company vehiciea. Śmoking would not even be allowed in a room rented for a private party or function.  Portunately, there is still an opportunity ta emend ox even prevent the proposed workplace smoking rules. Trom now until August 13, OSHA will accept public comment on the workplace amoking ban. To have your comments entered into the official OSHA file on this issue, please follow these thrae simple steps: 1. Take a few minutes to write a brief letter telling OŚHA that designated smoking areaa are preferable to the Severe p restrictions row being considered; 3 2. Make three copies oż your letter (this ia to comply with 4 federal law; z 3. put your original letter, along with the three copies e inside one envelope and mail ta: 8  OSHA Docket ni Docket Ko. H-122

Text Adam: May 30, 1974 To: RLL Marketing Departnent Personnel This ręquesta your assistance in attaining tighter security of zensitive Company information which you posaess or to which you may have access. Security is a necessary discipline at all times in business operations but is especially critical to the Company at this time due to the vast number and significance of many projects in which we are currently involved--and especially in view of recent "leaks" of new brand and promotional/ advertising programs under development. Disclosure of such information can be of substantial advantage to our competitore and works to undermine the hard work and dedication which all of us try to bring to our contripution_to. Company growth and profita, Accordingly, effective immediately, we're adopting the following program to asure that information remaine confidential to those parties directly involved with any sensitive Company matter: | 1. Our Own Attitudes - Any program of this nature requires each of us to become more concerned about the harm that disclosure of sensitive information can cause. Thus, we must aszese the sensitivity of all matters we deal with and  , treat each one according to its degree of confidentiality. II. Need to Knoy - Only those parties needing access to sensitive Tniofnation in Order to mako theżr contribution Ło the subject should have access to it. This means: A. No copies are to be mada of documents entitied TI) "Confidential" (unless the originating party grants permission for such copies) or (2) "Secret" (except by the originator). B. No casuał conversation of the subject with any party not directly involved with the matter, including menbers of your family, - €. No smoking of developmental products except behind closed doors. ui. Wernex, engineer, proprietor of Nels E. Werner Company, Board Member of Webcox, suggested "this may be a-propitious time" to bring to your attention my ideas regarding the probable role of nicotine in regulating the flow of nicotinic acid in tha body, the benefits that may derive if this concept is reliable, the harm that might obtain for many individuala should they abruptly or completely stop smoking, and the seemingly significant beneficial effect o£ smoking a cigarette which was observed by several of us in a human experimental situation where physiologically active mushroom material was administered in a project whose ultimate intent is to. davelop a technique to prevent cancer. My idea of working in cancer ia not new as you can tell - from tha enclosed abstract which was submitted with my application to the USPHS in October of 1961. The enclosed duplication of my April 3, 1962 letter to Senator Neuberger regarding this application, among other things, reveals a significant amount of cancer in my own family, yet I am continuing to smoke and naking this knowm to my. patients, since each day some are iuquiring what they should do. Relative to the USPHS application, the duplication of Senator Neuberger's reply to my above letter is meaningful, and we are awaiting a visit at our Institute from a local Congressman regarding the matter. I agree with Mr. Werner that the tobacco industry should — -—be-interested-.in-ny theme.— -go--that-T-might-'submit-in-sufficient,  -— explicit detail my ideaa and projected research, I suggest that
